cmCourseInfo.description: Transforming archaeological results into statements about people and their life ways. Covers basic archaeological theory, including research design, sampling, stratigraphy, seriation, formation and testing or evaluation of hypotheses, regional analyses. Introduces some of the major schools of archaeological theory, including New Archaeology and Post-Processual Archaeology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeological Interpretation

cmCourseInfo.description: An analysis of ethics in contemporary archaeology that covers reburial and repatriation, interpretation of the archaeological record in the context of historically oppressed groups, ethnic minorities, and non-western societies, the ethics of collecting and managing cultural property, relationships with the media, the debates surrounding looting, and other issues.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology, Ethics, and the Public

cmCourseInfo.description: Techniques for making archaeological data meaningful after excavation or survey. Archaeological measurements, compilation of data, database design, archaeological systematics, and sampling theory in the context of lithics, pottery, floral, faunal and other archaeological remains.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeological Laboratory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1 and a half statistics course (e.g. GGR270H1*, STA220H1, STA221H1, STA257H1, STA261H1, ANTC35H3**. Note: *Geography Pre- or co-requisites waived for Anthropology and Archaeology students; ** to be taken at the Scarborough Campus

breadthTypes.description: BR=5 The Physical and Mathematical Universes

cmCourseInfo.description: Opportunity for students participating in non-degree credit archaeological digs to submit reports, field notes and term papers for degree credit. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Field Archaeology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Permission of Undergraduate Co-ordinator and Supervisor

sections.name: LEC5101
sections.subTitle: Identity, Practice and Taboo: Anthropological Perspectives on Human-Animal Interactions

cmCourseInfo.description: Taught by an advanced PhD student or postdoctoral fellow, and based on his or her doctoral research and area of expertise, this course presents a unique opportunity to explore intensively a particular Archaeology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Emerging Scholarship (Archaeology)

cmCourseInfo.description: Laboratory or practical research on an archaeological project that emphasizes methods and research design in archaeology. Students must obtain the consent of a Supervisor before enrolling. Students are required to give an oral presentation of research results to an open meeting of the Archaeology Centre at the conclusion of the course. Application must be made to the Anthropology Department. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology Research Practicum
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A minimum of 14 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

To enrol in this course, please contact Josie Alaimo, the Undergraduate Administrator, at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca
